Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Expectation2: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation2: Steady rain and frequent lane changes from nearby cars raise the risk of sudden stops
Story:
The rain drummed steadily on the windshield as I navigated the slick streets, my hands tight on the steering wheel. My phone buzzed on the seat beside me—another message from my brother, reminding me not to be late for Mom’s birthday dinner. I could almost hear his voice, teasing but insistent: “Don’t bail on us again, okay?” I wanted to be there, to laugh and share stories, to be the sister everyone expected—present, reliable, part of the family.

But the city was a mess tonight. Headlights blurred in the rain, and cars darted unpredictably between lanes. As a taxi driver, I knew I had to stay focused, keep my passengers safe, and obey every traffic law, no matter how much I wanted to rush. The pressure built inside me—family waiting on one side, my duty to my passengers on the other. I glanced at the clock, feeling the minutes slip away, torn between the warmth of home and the cold responsibility of the road. My heart pounded as I weighed which role I would have to disappoint.
